'Now, everyone wants to know:When will you get the code required for mining? When can you begin mining? And where can you learn more, or connect with the team?The present memo is our first official, public status update on the development of Nockchain, so we're now happy to answer these three questions.We will release the source code shortly after the completion of our internal consensus testing.We will then go live with a minimalist, bare-bones mainnet (which we call the "dumbnet") within a matter of weeks after publishing the source code. The dumbnet will not be a testnet, but a scope-minimized first version of our live, public mainnet.Also as of today, we are officially opening the Nockchain community with two new places where developers, friends, and cultural entrepreneurs are welcome to interact with us and each other.'

Jock is an experimental language at present that is currently in development. Jock compiles to the Nock instruction set. Covenants / lock scripts on Nockchain are Nock scripts.Jock is the language we expect most NockApps will be written in, but right now most of them use Hoon because it’s a more mature language (but very esoteric).If you’re looking for app examples, the best repo to look is NockApp, our application framework. NockApp is our suggested toolkit for building apps that interact with Nockchain, as the integration will be very easy.
Logan any plans to be able to purchase a hard copy of the lite paper?
Or an online release of the paper
None at present! For now it’s limited release in certain venues.
Do owners of the paper have an advantage over others?

There aren’t recommended mining specs in the paper. There is useful information in the lightpaper for people deciding whether they want to mine or take other more active roles in the ecosystem. The lightpaper will be released prior to mainnet.

Okay, thank you! Just asking bc having an advantage over others would speak less in favor of a fair launch 🫡  But before dumbnet is still fair i guess 📈
There have always been information asymmetries, even in Bitcoin’s launch. Such is life! For more on our thinking about fair launches, read here:https://zorp.io/blog/fair-launch
At end of day we can do our best to even things out initially and then let the mining competition play out.

The Nockchain technical forum is open for more technical questions about NockApp, Jock, (or eventually Nockchain): https://forum.nockchain.orgFor more information about Nockchain: https://x.com/zorpzk/status/1864696427064000752?s=46Note that the team has currently not suggested any particular hardware or specification for mining. All information on mining will be revealed in public blog posts.
You can ask here too, but for more complex questions or if you want a lot of detail / to follow up in a conversation, the forum is best.

I saw your speech on youtube and you mentioned GPU (integrated memory). The circuit generation and proof process of zk-STARK is highly parallel, which is particularly suitable for the multi-core parallel architecture of GPU. Why do you choose CPU now? Is there any new change?
in the beginning they will use cpu
This is mostly just a matter of practicality in shipping highly novel research into production. Devices with integrated memory are still a good idea as far as future-proof versatile hardware goes.

Thank you for your answer. I fully understand that practicality and compatibility are important considerations when turning novel research into production applications. This pragmatic attitude is very important to promote the practical application of zk-STARK. When choosing a CPU at present, is it mainly due to hardware cost, development ecosystem, or other factors (such as technical barriers to performance optimization)?
I encourage everyone to do performance optimization, and I imagine over time we’ll move to GPU mining, and eventually even ASIC mining of ZKPs.

You mentioned that you encourage everyone to optimize performance. Are there any recommended directions for performance optimization (such as circuit optimization, length of proof generation time, or hardware architecture equipment)? How can the community developer team participate in this process?
It’ll be more clear once we post the open-source reference implementation of the mining node! (Pretty sure we’re going with MIT license)
Thank you for sharing! The choice of an open source mining node reference implementation and MIT license is very community friendly and exciting!

I would love to see ZK ASIC coming to live supporting a standard set of ZK primitives, because the main barrier to technical main stream adaption is ZK compute overhead is still cost prohiibitive either via prime ring or eplliptic curves.
Hey guys. I’m pretty new to mining.

mining for a specific coin isn’t available yet, it's impossible to pinpoint the exact best CPU for mining that coin. However, when mining becomes available, you can evaluate the ideal CPU for the job by visiting resources like Hashrate.no, which provides detailed information on CPU performance, efficiency, and profitability for mining various cryptocurrencies.
